chapter.title: v1.0.26 Infrastructure Maintenance, July 24, 2013
chapter.para: This is not a code release, but rather infrastructure maintenance for the v1.0.26 release.

note.para: This maintenance does not apply to the ORD datacenter, which will be performed at a later date.

listitem.para: Update MySQL to incorporate the latest bug fixes and security patches.
Database instance optimizations.
Updated all MySQL versions to 5.1.66.

Applied configuration enhancements for all instances. The following are the changes we are making to 512MB customers instances, with the exception of the innodb_log_buffer_size change, which will apply to all instances:
key_buffer_size = 50M -> 40M
innodb_buffer_pool_size = 150M -> 125M
innodb_log_buffer_size = 25M -> 4M (512MB) 8M (all other flavor sizes)
tmp_table_size = 16M -> 12M
max_heap_table_size = 16M -> 12M
table_open_cache = 256 -> 200
table_definition_cache = 256 -> 200
max_user_connections = 100 -> 75
max_connections = 110 -> 85
Removed container disk reservations for root.
Adjusted maximum connections per instance.
Backported instance apt repo source list to include localized mirror for:
Cloud Monitoring
Percona XtraBackup
Installed Percona XtraBackup in instances that did not have the package installed.

D-12677: The following changes have been made for the Grant User Access, Create User, and Revoke User Access API calls:

Grant User Access and Create User – Users created with the Grant User Access and Create User calls are no longer given the MySQL GRANT OPTION permission. This is the permission that allows a user to grant and revoke his / her own access permissions to / from other users.
Revoke User Access – The Revoke User Access call will also now remove GRANT OPTION from non-root users. Root users still have GRANT OPTION.

chapter.title: v1.0.6, August 1, 2012
chapter.para: We’re pleased to announce the availability of Rackspace Cloud Databases to all US and UK Open Cloud customers. These release notes cover the Unlimited Availability (UA) release of Rackspace Cloud Databases.

listitem.para: Provision MySQL database instances of varying flavor (RAM) sizes without the need to maintain and/or update MySQL. Optionally create users and databases during instance creation for quick deployment.

Critical loads with high I/O demands are performance-optimized and protected with local RAID 10 and network RAID 10. Additionally, network RAID provides synchronous replication of volumes with automatic failover and load balancing across available storage clusters.
Increase storage allocation seamlessly without downtime as your dataset size increases.
Increase or decrease flavor (RAM) size as database input/output (I/O) demands increase.
Create, list, and delete databases on your MySQL database instance.
Control database access by adding and removing MySQL users. Optionally enable root user access for additional control.
Performance improvements.
Documentation updates to the CDB Developer Guide.
Removed root user from the users list.
List users no longer shows root (or any other specified users we define).
XML Pagination works for list instances.
Kernel openvz updates.
Added Environment field to usage payload xml.
Separate the modify event into modify volume/flavor types.
Added categories searching for atom hopper billing.
Users' database privileges are not modifiable. Users must be deleted and recreated to add additional database privileges.
